okay hello everyone my name is Jose caros I work as a support engineer at chronosphere and I'm also a Myer of
fluent bit project uh fluent bit for the those of you that might not know it it's
a project Under the Umbrella of the fluent organization the previously uh
graduated project is fluentd what we do uh we know that telary data is growing at very big uh
Rat and having a lot of data about your systems is a great thing but it can also be a pain and we try to solve this pains
like latency in collection ingestion and processing among among other things like lack of standardization which our
friends from Prometheus and open Telemetry are trying to deal with as well however at the end of the day what
we really uh want to achieve is the data analysis and how we deal with this uh is
through our proposition of uh collecting this data and pre-processing with fluent bit we collect your data from many
sources and many formats log metrics traces and now also profiling to put
this information together for the people that will take decisions based on this data analysis and we also have uh to
deal with the challenge of the microservices architecture and make all this uh data collection and processing
uh scalable and of course the user expectation of having great performance
at no cost right so what is our proposal to uh collect these different data
sources and send it to any destination that you have that's fluent bit that's what we try to do and we develop this
based in some key principles uh one is that it is optimized for Speed and
efficiency meaning that we have a very low footprint and hence reducing the
energy uh consumption we are fully open source and vendor agnostic or vendor
neutral and that means that uh we have support and integration with popular ecosystems like Prometheus and open
Telemetry we have an extensive pluging ecosystem and and you can deploy fluent
bit in the cloud on premise or Edge deployment fluent bit this year is
turning 10 years old so uh it's pretty pretty ready for production and it had
been adopted by Major uh Cloud providers out there so what is new inversion four
which we're releasing this week we have implemented a head sampling for your uh
traces meaning that at the beginning of receiving the data you can take a decision and drop some of the traces
that you're receiving and we're also implementing tail sampling which means you're going to buffer some of your
traces and then take a decision based on conditions later on whether to uh allow
this data to go through or to drop it uh some time ago we introduced lock
processors in flu bit to uh improve efficiency and now we're adding conditionals to the same so you will
only process those log that um match these uh conditions that you can
introduce as you can see there are many uh operators there in the security side for TLS we
are enabling the ability to specify allow TLS versions and also to pick the
uh ciphers for it and we have also implemented uh much requested uh feature
to set uh variables from the file system and on the experimental side we are
adding uh support for the Z language this is in addition to the existing
support for wasm go and LU scripting and the advantage of this is that it will be
using fluent bit internals via the new SDK that means you will need less code
it will be closer to C hence improving uh interoperability and why Zig because
we think is probably going to be the next go rust out there for example goes
TTY if you know it is written in Zig uh we will have one talk at the

Jonah John hey everyone Jonah Cowell I'm the
SVP of product and design at peser and I'm here to give you some updates on
joerger we had a very exciting year uh but first I'm going to tell you a little bit about what joerger does in case
you're not familiar I won't tell you about tracing because I think you've all heard that story many times jger is
essentially an analytics and storage system for Trace data so we allow you to
do data collection storage and then also visualization so this is a view of a
bunch of different traces coming into Jer and kind of how you visualize the
data you can drill down get pretty deep into all of the data and constructs
inside the traces uh so this is how you would drill down into an issue and diagnose for example a database issue
that you may be having um and it also helps you understand the performance of
your application where you can optimize it how you can make it higher performing
so in this kind of case uh putting some asynchronous calls or threading in your
code would speed this application up for example so certain patterns are very easy to detect and jerger makes it nice
and easy to visualize that um we also have a lot of other visualizations
besides your typical timeline U this is a flame graph view there's lots of different ways to compare and analyze
your Trace data uh joerger is generally agnostic so there's lots of ways to do the data
storage uh we interoperate with other tracing systems very easily and of
course open Telemetry is the main way to get your data into joerger we have made
a pretty big architecture change to Jager which we officially launched version to late last year right before
cubec Con in the US um but I wanted to tell you about this big change because
now we actually are very native to the entire open Telemetry ecosystem and The
Collector we're still releasing version one and version two every month as
maintainers uh but version one will be deprecated by the end of this calendar year so if you're still using Jagger V1
it's time to move and there's a lot of good reasons to move we really rebuilt
uh jger around open Telemetry so instead of having a jagger collector we now have
a modified version of the open Telemetry collector um and we've also rebuilt our
storage apis to be modern and fully integrated with otel in The Collector uh
we still support all of the storage in jerger V1 so if you have historical data
it'll still work with B2 everything is compatible all of the different uh data
structures are that way and now we support OTP uh oltp natively actually in the
storage system so uh the way that we store even though the schema may be
different than some of the other Solutions uh we support that natively um
we've also simplified things considerably so we've made it so that the same binary which is basically a
modified uh version of The Collector can be used in a lot of different ways so
you could use it uh just to deal with storage you could use it for data collection and sampling there's a lot of
different ways you can use it so in the config which you can see an example of here this probably looks very familiar
to many of you because it's essentially an otel config with a few different
components that we have built for Jager in order for it to work
um we're doing some other interesting things like using the extension capability in The Collector to expose
our UI uh so we we've done a lot of really interesting things to extend the
collector for lots of different use cases out there um so essentially it's the same
binary the Jagger collector can be deployed as a collector as a querier uh
you can even use it for queuing and various other things so this is kind of how the architecture looks with V2 uh
it's very similar to V1 but things are a bit uh simpler in terms of just having
different configs um so just a one other piece is
we've built span the ability to derive metrics from spans uh into the collector
and into jger so we can emit data directly from Jager into Prometheus and
then we can visualize those inside our UI or you can visualize them and Percy
or grafana or whatever you're you're using inside um your metrics environment
as well uh but now it's fully integrated so you don't have to make additional
configurations um a couple key things uh that we've done since the last time I
was here speaking in Europe uh We've obviously done a lot of enhancements
modifications we're supporting new backends like the latest versions of elastic search uh and we've done a lot
of updates we now have a Helm chart we have a kuber Net's operator uh We've
made a lot of other improvements uh for Jagger V2 specifically you can now use
Kafka natively because of the otel support which is improved over what we
had in Jer V1 if you're dealing with queuing um and then we built a bunch of
new capabilities in the UI these are a few pieces that we built in the last year to
make the UI better make performance analysis better um and there's more uh
coming we have some really great stuff in the road map uh new visualizations in
the UI specifically for topologies which are always really tricky with Trace data
so we're actually redoing a lot of the UI for topology views uh making things
more seamless and streamlined and then on the back end side we are adding
official support for click house so that's work in progress and we're doing some interesting things with open search
like deriving metrics in real time versus having to calculate them so lots
of cool stuff coming uh you'll definitely hear about it in the next six months because a lot of these are
progressing um and that's kind of the quick update on what's going on and with that I'm going to hand it off to Austin
